Quick Encounter

A weasel and cat scamper about the room, the two clearly responsible for the scratches and gouges in the furniture here. A homonculus watches motionless, perhaps even being mistaken for a statue. If the party enters the room, the cat and weasel scamper as far away and out of site as they can rather than attack. The creatures are the familiars of the cultists in the cauldron room nearby, and will alert the cultists to stage an ambush if the familiars see the party.

 

  • 1@Compendium[dnd5e.monsters.WOdeacKCYVhgLDuN]{Weasel} (10XP each)
  • 1@Compendium[dnd5e.monsters.hIf83RD3ZVW4Egfi]{Cat} (10XP each)
  • 1@Compendium[dnd5e.monsters.ZQTCZfTV9ZoTjNCU]{Homunculus} (10XP each)

text.content:
Corrupted Church and Graveyard.

 

Highlights and Functionality:

  • Modular components can be swapped out
  • Mausoleums stairs can be unhidden and used as egress to the church or other dungeon
  • Grave under the trees can be dug up (double-click by GM)
  • Ambient dark chanting in the church
  • Ambient distant thunder

 

Modules in use:

  • FXMaster for weather
  • Monk's Active Tile Triggers for the grave and crypt lids
  • Multiface Tile to quickly change crypt lids, statues, and headstones
  • Multilevel Token module for teleporting to the church. 
    • Note1: Requires the Unholy Church scene to be in your world
    • Note2: You may need to link the teleporters. See Multilevel Token tutorial.

cf.path: Baileywiki Nuts and Bolts#/CF_SEP/Scene Notes

text.content:
Welcome. I'm Baileywiki, and thanks for trying out my maps for Foundry VTT. Some things you want to know:

UPDATE 10/22/20: Now using core Foundry lighting so Dancing Lights module is no longer needed. Added lots of special new lighting effects to this one!

Maps Be Upgradable!

These maps are all free. But most of these maps also have (or will have) the ability to be upgraded and customized. Clear out a dilapidated mansion and then work to take it over as a base. Turn a wizard's room into a cleric's temple... or a druid's garden. Commandeer a sailing vessel and upgrade it over time.

I have a Patreon for fans who value this kind of extensibility of game play at https://www.patreon.com/baileywiki 

 

Modules in Use (Optional)

Whenever possible, I use the following modules. You'll want to get your hands on them for the full effect:

  • Multilevel Tokens: I create automatic teleport points to get your players around the map. I also project players from one level so players on another level can see them.
  • Token Magic FX: Special effects on some maps, including a shimming effect on the Pocket Dimension Mansion.
  • Parallaxia: This module lets you animate tiles, like water running by and other nifty things.
  • FXMaster: Lots of great weather and special effects for your maps.

 

About the Magic Shop

The Magic Shop has 4 distinct rooms featuring various ambient sounds and lots of special lights:

  1. Main shop area with loft
  2. Backroom kitchen, workshop and storage
  3. Bedroom and bathroom
  4. Secret glyph/teleport room accessible through a secret entrance behind the bookshelf in the bedroom

 

Modules in Use: Dancing Lights

Upcoming Upgrades: Planning on different shop and building types which will eventually snap or link together to form a town/street area, or just create different places of interest for you to drop into your own urban environments. I'll also provide damaged and unfurnished versions of this.

 

Communicate with me anytime at my Discord or via Patreon.

cf.path: Baileywiki Nuts and Bolts#/CF_SEP/Scene Notes#/CF_SEP/City

text.content:
The Manor Alley East is fashioned loosely after Trollskull Alley. It can be used as a connecting point to the Manor Alley East, or as a separate part of a city. There are 3 "Weathers Conditions" available for the alley.

Parts of this scene were constructed using the Baileywiki Modular Towns System to build multi-floor structures and add clutter to the space. If you would like more of these modular elements, become a patron.

 

Walkthrough

A walkthrough of this content and its features is available on YouTube. Check out the full video here.

 

Weather Conditions

  • Peacefull: This "standard" condition featuring peaceful clouds.
  • Muddy: Dirtied up streets during a rainstorm, with appropriate rain and denser cloud cover.
  • Snowy: Drifts and flurries swirl about the snow-covered roofs of this weather condition.

 

Key Features

  • Multistory buildings. There are a total of 3 navigable buildings in the Manor Alley East:
    • Center - Apartments and empty shops
    • South - A blacksmith with armor and weapons shops; wine and ale vendors; meeting room/office; and apartments
    • East -   A church; general store; equipment store; printing press/news outlet; and apartments
  • Clickable Teleports via Monk's Active Tile Triggers to travel to Manor Alley West and the Manor
  • Dynamic lighting that also changes when the motif changes
  • Facade buildings throughout the alley, each of which can be swapped out for a real building
  • The chimneys feature animated or still versions of the smoke, using the control panel

 

Modules in Use

  • Levels / Better Roofs / Wall Height: The triumverate of modules for 3-dimensional mapping
  • FXMaster: Clouds rolling by, except for over the navigable buildings.
  • Monk's Active Tile Triggers with Tagger. Powers the controls in the margin of the scene.
  • Token Magic FX. Creates a satisfying drop shadow on roofs.
  • Token Attacher. For prefabs.

 

For support, find me on Discord.

The torture chamber is filled with foul smelling water. The stench of blood, and defecation from the Lord's poor victims permeates the air. Water-logged undead lunge out of the cages and rise from the water, hungry for the party.

text.content:
Welcome. I'm Baileywiki, and thanks for trying out my maps for Foundry VTT. Some things you want to know:

UPDATE 10/22/20: Now using core Foundry lighting so Dancing Lights module is no longer needed.

 

These Maps Be Upgradable!

These maps are all free. But most of these maps also have (or will have) the ability to be upgraded and customized. Clear out a dilapidated mansion and then work to take it over as a base. Turn a wizard's room into a cleric's temple... or a druid's garden. Commandeer a sailing vessel and upgrade it over time.

I have a Patreon for fans who value this kind of extensibility of game play at https://www.patreon.com/baileywiki 

 

Quick Tips

  1. The Multi-Level Token zones are controlled via map notes. Make sure that both you and your players have Map Notes Display set to True.
  2. If you would like to control whether players can use a specific zone, you can change the permissions of the given map note by changing between the @Compendium[baileywiki-nuts-and-bolts.journals.Ii2M77LabDmpHbGt]{stair} and @Compendium[baileywiki-nuts-and-bolts.journals.Ic3LUzSx7smMJBoB]{gm-only} journal entries. If you are using Scene Packer, then these entries will be imported and linked automatically.
  3. Many of the tiles, lights, drawings and sounds are locked in place by Token Attacher module. Use Token Attacher's Quick Edit mode to move most things around.

 

Modules in Use

The Baileywiki modules use a variety of 3rd party modules to make the technical magic possible. The current list of Required and Recommended modules can be found in this section of the Baileywiki Installation Guide & FAQ.

While only Token Attacher and Libwrapper are required, we highly recommend you use one of the suggested Module Loadouts to make the most of the technical features within the module.

 

About the Tavern

The tavern features a yawning pit that can serve as an access point to a dungeon (per the lore). There is a pulley system on the 2nd floor for raising/lowering adventuring parties. 

Modules in Use: Multilevel Token hotspots are in the main tavern eating area, projecting level 1 actors to be viewable from level 2.  Play around with the day/night lighting to find what you like best.

Special Use of Ambient Sounds: Crackling fires, dripping sounds in the beer hallway, sizzling stovetop, and an ominous wind blowing up from the yawning portal itself if you get close.

Upgrades: The Tavern also features a fighting pit instead of a yawning pit, as well as a music stage version with a dressing room in the back. Future upgrades will include basements to take you off in all kinds of adventures.

Features Rooms and Areas:

  1. Downstairs:
    1. Main dining hall with bar and booths that can accommodate tokens neatly.
    2. Private dining room
    3. Backroom: bathrooms, beer hallway, storage room and kitchen
  2. Upstairs:
    1. Upper dining area
    2. Lounge
    3. Lots of bedrooms of different sizes
    4. Two staircases in the bedroom area leading to level 1

 

Communicate with me anytime at my Discord or via Patreon.

cf.path: Baileywiki Nuts and Bolts#/CF_SEP/Module ReadMe's

text.content:
Welcome. I'm Baileywiki, and thanks for trying out my maps for Foundry VTT. Some things you want to know:

This Journal Entry is a general guide for using the Modular Town System and my maps. For the most up to date information  and guides, always check the Baileywiki Installation Guide & FAQ.

 

Video Guides

You can view release videos, system guides, and advanced tutorials on the Baileywiki YouTube Channel. Below are some helpful videos and playlists to have handy when getting started.

  • Installation and Getting Started Guide
  • Playlist of Release Videos: Modular System Releases
  • Playlist of guides to using the Modular system: Building with the Modular System
  • Playslist of Modular Map Walkthroughs: Baileywiki Map Walkthroughs
    • note: Some of these videos are for scenes and maps in the Baileywiki Maps Premium Towns module, if you think that you are missing one of the maps in the playlist, check the scenes compendium for Premium Towns.

Quick Tips

  1. IMPORT MACROS: Import all of the macros from the Premium Towns macro compendium, this will ensure that all of the extra features work. You only need to repeat this process if a specific macro is updated (see change notes)
  2. AGREE TO THE PROMPT: Say "yes" to the prompt to import compendium data into your Compendium tab. This is a special "system agnostic" Actor compendium that will be refreshed every time there is a new release.
  3. DELETE UNNEEDED ACTORS AND SCENES: Importing a large amount of scenes and actors can cause high load times and server instability. Only import scenes and prefabs that you are actively using. Once you have finished using prefabs to build a scene, delete the actors from your actor directory.

 

Modules in Use

The Baileywiki modules use a variety of 3rd party modules to make the technical magic possible. The current list of Required and Recommended modules can be found in this section of the Baileywiki Installation Guide & FAQ.

While only Token Attacher and Libwrapper are required, we highly recommend you use one of the suggested Module Loadouts to make the most of the technical features within the module.

 

About Baileywiki Maps

Baileywiki Maps are high quality scenes focused on reusability for your campaign. Most of the maps have alternate versions for you to make the most out of them. You may use the "Pocket Mansion" for one campaign as part of a magical item or portal that your players are rewarded with, then have the party of a different campaign find the "Ruined Mansion" early on with a goal to restore it to the "Furnished Mansion." All of the maps are designed to provide the greatest amount of utility possible for your campaigns without sacrificing quality.

 

Premium Version:

The Premium Maps feature variants for all of the "base" maps and premium placeables, such as multi-level Ship prefabs using Levels. If you are also using Modular Town, there are deployable Facades that can be placed into a scene and then linked back to the corresponding Premium Map.

Performance Considerations: The larger your map and the more elements you include, the more performance will suffer. Consider making a series of small maps that you link together with Multilevel Token module. Also, modules like FXMaster can be amazing for weather elements, or Token Magic FX for cool tile and token effects, but you can turn them off for immediate performance gains.

 

Communicate with me anytime at my Discord or via Patreon. 

Asset and Update Information

Changelogs

Changelogs can be viewed under the Modular Town Releases section of the Baileywiki Modular System Guide.

Included Assets

A summary of the Modular Town assets can be viewed under the Modular Town Assets section of the Baileywiki Modular System Guide.

All of the artwork and sounds within the module can be found in the path. You'll find tiles, thumbnails, and icons in the "maps" subfolder and the sounds under the "sounds" subfolder.

The extra assets are great for building your own scenes without using the prefab actors. You will also occasionally find easter eggs for future releases in the folders, so be sure to look through the asset files regularly.

 

Additional Tips

  1. Don't delete multiple control tokens at once. Do it one at a time or you'll get artifacts. 
  2. Hold CTR when rotating assets or use the arrow keys to quickly rotate them 
  3. If after placing an asset the image is laying on top of another image, use the Tile tool to move it to the back. it won't hurt anything
  4. There are many ambient sounds and some loops included in the module files. Check em out.
  5. Instead of using the Actor assets, you can deploy images directly from the module files
  6. When you are done setting up your scene, "select all" actors and then right click one of them to make all of the control tokens invisible to your players
  7. Use walls to close off parts of the map to your players 

 

Have a Problem or Questions? 

Communicate with me anytime at my Discord (best) or via Patreon.

Quick Encounter

As the party makes their way up the creaking belfry stairs, they hear a rustle in the rafters, followed by a low hum, then... silence. Once they reach the top of the belfry stairs and approach the bell the hum returns followed by an electric snap as two phase spiders return from the ethereal plane and attack the party.

 

  • 2@Compendium[dnd5e.monsters.llSG0Hi4eGlRlQ4o]{Phase Spider} (700XP each)
  • 5@Compendium[dnd5e.monsters.4udpeEneFSZK9NTB]{Swarm of Spiders} (100XP each)

text.content:
Welcome. I'm Baileywiki, and thanks for trying out my maps for Foundry VTT. Some things you want to know:

UPDATE 10/22/20: Now using core Foundry lighting so Dancing Lights module is no longer needed.

These Maps Be Upgradable!

These maps are all free. But most of these maps also have (or will have) the ability to be upgraded and customized. Clear out a dilapidated mansion and then work to take it over as a base. Turn a wizard's room into a cleric's temple... or a druid's garden. Commandeer a sailing vessel and upgrade it over time.

I have a Patreon for fans who value this kind of extensibility of game play at https://www.patreon.com/baileywiki 

 

Modules in Use (Optional)

Whenever possible, I use the following modules. You'll want to get your hands on them for the full effect:

  • Multilevel Tokens: I create automatic teleport points to get your players around the map. I also project players from one level so players on another level can see them.
  • Token Magic FX: Special effects on some maps, including a shimming effect on the Pocket Dimension Mansion.
  • Wall Height: For maps with walls that can be seen under or over by certain players when flying, for example.
  • Parallaxia: This module lets you animate tiles, like water running by and other nifty things.
  • FXMaster: Lots of great weather and special effects for your maps.

 

About the Mansion

The Mansion comes in two varieties, "normal" and Pocket Dimension (Mordenkainen). But you can further customize the landscape.

Landscape Customization: Just to go into the source files in the module and look from Snow, Grass or Void terrains. Make these the background or drop them in as a PNG. 

Transparent PNGs: You also have the PNG files for each level in case you want to drop them into another map.

Modules in Use: If you have Multilevel Tokens, Dancing Lights and Token Magic FX, you'll find those all work on this map. Also, Token Magic FX is used in the Pocket Mansion in order to shimmer the background.

Available Upgrades: Patreons get snap-in PNGs to turn every section of the Mansion into a ruined wreck or to unfurnish everything. Future changes include new room types.

Remember, the Mansion has 3 levels. If you import all 3 levels, the teleports should work.

Communicate with me anytime at my Discord or via Patreon.

 

About the Mansion Level 2

The second level of the mansion features a number of staircases with automatic teleportation and the following areas:

  1. Foyer/entrance (featuring Multilevel Token target area for seeing actors on Level 1)
  2. Landing
  3. Tower wizards room (bottom-left)
  4. Bedrooms
  5. Large bedroom (top-right)
  6. Dining Room (featuring Multilevel Token projection area for seeing actors on Level 1)
  7. Master bedroom (top-left)

cf.path: Baileywiki Nuts and Bolts#/CF_SEP/Scene Notes

text.content:
Welcome to the Colosseum. Blood sport feeds the hungry mob within these walls. You hear the chanting of the crowd from your meager cell.  The prince and his entourage is in attendance. Are you going to give them a show?

 

The Colosseum features a modular design:

 

  1. Create any size battle area using the "arena curve" and "arena straight" seating prefabs
  2. Add a "throne Viewing Balcony" prefab
  3. The battle area is transparent, so put any kind of terrain, traps and obstacles as background tiles. Consider optimizing with DF Architect module.
  4. The vertical doors on the surrounding walls are pre-configured to teleport to interior rooms, arranged in the scene margins. Add more rooms from the modular castle or c1 building systems! If you don't want to use a door, just delete it or right-click and hide it/deactive it 
  5. The trap doors laying flat on the ground will spawn enemies randomly from the "Arena Battles" roll table. Hide these tiles if you want to surprise your characters. And you can customize the enemy deployment using Quick Encounters.

 

It's in 3D!!

This map is available in 3D using Ripper's 3d Canvas module. You may prefer to use this for exposition rather than actual gameplay.

 

Modules in Use:

  • Token Attacher to power prefabs
  • Levels, Wall Heigh and Better Roffs (for multilayer functionality)
  • Monk's Active Tiles to power the teleports and trap doors 
  • 3d Canvas to render the map in 3D 
  • Quick Encounters to spawn enemies

The armory is choked with dust, but there is good equipment still here. If the party should let their curiosity get the best of them and pick up one of the blades it will humm to life before glowing blue and flying from their hands. The blades will rise as a group of Flying Swords and three Dust Mephits will peek out of the grime to ward the party away from their derelect home.

  • 3@Compendium[dnd5e.monsters.BUCfQ7ihaXX75Vai]{Dust Mephit} (100XP each)

text.content:
Your tokens (and/or tiles) and their positions have been saved in this Journal Entry and replaced with a single Quick Encounter Note. To run the Quick Encounter, double-click the Map Note icon and then click the Run Quick Encounter button.

Quick Encounter

If  the party avoided conflict in the heart chamber and quietly approaches this level of the tower, the torturemaster here will be unaware of their presence.

A torturemaster (Veteran) cleans the slightly rusted manacles of the table in the center of this room, the most recent victim having already been disposed of. The torturemaster's two assistants are hell-hounds given to him by the Lord of the Castle for his loyal service. Neither the torturemaster, nor the hellhounds can be convinced to betray the Lord.

If the torturemaster here's the party coming, he will rouse the hellhound that sleeps near the chest and direct the other to wait for the party to come up the stairs. As soon as the party is within range, the hellhound near the stairs will unleash its firebreath upon the party. The other hellhound will leap down to block off the exit, and the torturemaster will advance upon the party from the top of the stairs.

 

  • 2@Compendium[dnd5e.monsters.iSCL4Q82ivnYelzc]{Hell Hound} (700XP each)
  • 1@Compendium[dnd5e.monsters.J8xjoG4Dxb8WkHtV]{Veteran} (700XP each)

text.content:
Quick Encounter

The cook for the poachers is a commoner from the nearby town. They were pressed into service by the poachers after getting lost in the woods. While they are presumed dead by the townsfolk and have already been mourned, a rescue would be quite celebrated. The cook is not hostile and is more likely to be afraid of the party than confrontational.

So long as the poachers are not immediately nearby to interfere and the party is friendly, the cook will provide information on the hideout:

  • There is a hidden passage between the kitchen and the bunk room
  • There are 8 poachers (3 Scouts, 5 Bandits) and the boss (Druid)
  • The boss uses nature magic and controls most everything. Other poachers not likely to put up much of a fight after the boss is down
  • 1@Compendium[dnd5e.monsters.SqZRuJ8lt2KGJBbq]{Commoner} (10XP each)

text.content:
Welcome. I'm Baileywiki, and thanks for trying out my maps for Foundry VTT. Some things you want to know:

For a complete walkthrough of the Tower, watch the YouTube Video. (Spoilers ahead!)

These Maps Be Upgradable!

Most of my base maps are free to everyone. But all of my maps also have the ability to be upgraded and customized. Clear out a dilapidated mansion and then work to take it over as a base. Turn a wizard's room into a cleric's temple... or a druid's garden. Commandeer a sailing vessel and upgrade it over time. Or get extra floors a Keep or a 11-story Wizard's tower.

I have a Patreon for fans who value this kind of extensibility of game play at https://www.patreon.com/baileywiki 

 

Quick Tips

  1. The Multi-Level Token zones are controlled via map notes. Make sure that both you and your players have Map Notes Display set to True.
  2. If you would like to control whether players can use a specific zone, you can change the permissions of the given map note by changing between the @Compendium[baileywiki-nuts-and-bolts.journals.Ii2M77LabDmpHbGt]{stair} and @Compendium[baileywiki-nuts-and-bolts.journals.Ic3LUzSx7smMJBoB]{gm-only} journal entries. If you are using Scene Packer, then these entries will be imported and linked automatically.
  3. Many of the tiles, lights, drawings and sounds are locked in place by Token Attacher module. Use Token Attacher's Quick Edit mode to move most things around.

 

Modules in Use

The Baileywiki modules use a variety of 3rd party modules to make the technical magic possible. The current list of Required and Recommended modules can be found in this section of the Baileywiki Installation Guide & FAQ.

While only Token Attacher and Libwrapper are required, we highly recommend you use one of the suggested Module Loadouts to make the most of the technical features within the module.

 

About the Tower

For a complete walkthrough of the Tower, watch the YouTube Video. (Spoilers ahead!)

The first four levels of the Tower are free to everyone. The other levels, custom skins, and the teleporter are for premium subscribers.

If you use all the levels, this is a massive 11-story tower (12 if you count the roof). There are relatively mundane levels, like guest rooms, library and dining room, and decidedly sinister and magical levels, like a portal room, a scrying pool and a laboratory where dark experiments have been taking place.

Modules in Use: Multilevel Token hotspots are in place to teleport your players around and to project them from level to another. And Token Attacher is useful if you want to drop any of the Tower levels (including walls, lights and sound) into any map or on top of any of the customizable tower "base" styles that are available to you (city/cobble, moat/grass, or remote/dirt). Lastly, CommunityLighting by Blitz is used to create the electric strobe effect in the laboratory.

Special Use of Ambient Sounds: In many of the levels of the Tower, you can hear fire crackling, magic aura's and electrical ambient sounds to help set the mood.

 

Communicate with me anytime at my Discord or via Patreon. 

 

Important DM Notes for Advanced Functionality

Activating Teleports: Install and activate Multilevel Token. To actually trigger a teleport, a token must be standing in the hot spot and click on the Journal Entry in that zone.

Using the special Teleport Pad from the Actor compendium (requires Token Attacher module and Multielevel Token Module): You can drag a TP pad from the compendium onto you map. Then you can edit it there to point to any destination you want. It comes with sound, lights and even the Multilevel Token area and journal entry required to function. You just need to edit the distination!

Import All Maps. You must import all of the maps you want to teleport to or else the teleporter will not function. It needs the destination to exist after all.

 

List of Rooms/Features

NOTE ON CUSTOMIZING THE ROOM ORDER: Some rooms naturally link up with staircases while others don't. If you would like to use a different order of rooms, or leave some out entirely, you can do that! You will have to change any teleport linkages, of course. And if you run into a situation where staircases don't line up, just use the Deployable Teleporter token in your Actor compendium as a hack to get your players where they need to go next!

LVL01: Entrance: A large room, flexible enough to furnish or leave empty. A staircase leads upwards, and a subtle teleport hotspot can receive tokens teleporting from elsewhere to here. You have multiple options for a foundation to your tower. To change the base of the tower, watch the walkthrough video!

LVL02: Magic Room: a mysterious arcane power emanates from the pool surrounding this room. Another teleport pad waits to receive

LVL03: Guest Rooms: A handful of bedrooms, a secret teleportation room behind a metal door, and a couple other rooms that seem to be used for spying through the pictures or mirrors in the bedrooms.

LVL04: Library: Tall shelves of books and a few arcane artifacts tip off that a mage does their studying here.

LVL05: Dining Room: A decidedly magical dining experience with floating candles and a balcony to survey the surrounding landscape.

LVL06: Portal Room: 4 Portals to who-knows-where. Are these even active anymore? Right-click the portal light to turn the portal on/off. Double-click it to change the color.

LVL07: Scrying Pool: The tiles around the pool are worn away. Maybe from the magic essence of the pool. Or maybe from the endless of hours someone has stood staring into the secrets of the world.

LVL08: Laboratory: Something sinister is happening here. Why are there footprints coming from that empty tank over there?

LVL09: Beasts and Cages: Our good mage has been keeping something in here. Or something got out.

LVL10: Lair: Something lurks in that bone-covered cave. And the empty chains on the walls imply it's been well fed.

LVL11: Bedroom: This is literally where the magic happens. Between the magical dressing room to the floating wardrobe, this room has ample opportunity for mahem and discovery.

LVL12: Roof(s): You have two options for a roof: A castle roof with arcane sigils protecting from intrudors, or a normal shingled roof to top off the tower.

cf.path: Baileywiki Nuts and Bolts#/CF_SEP/Scene Notes#/CF_SEP/Docks

text.content:
The Wharfmaster dock is the central hub for commercial use of the docks, including payment of dock fees, import tarriffs, and dispute mediation when needed. A large sum of moneys and goods can be found in the vaults any given day.

The warehouse on the dock also features a speakeasy and casino on the second floor, where sailors can often be found.

The docks are large here, capable of accommodating the largest of see vessels. 

 

 

Modules in use:

- Token Attacher: If you drag ship prefabs like the Galleon, Frigate or Triremes. The docks is plenty long to accommodate a couple of large ships. You can also swivel the loading cranes using the control token. The crane is set as an overhead tile with a high z value so it can swivel over a ship in dock.

- Levels, Better Roofs and Wall Height for the second floor of the warehouse 

 

Other suggestions:

- CUSTOMIZE: Rearrange the docks as you like using the tiles. Double-click any dock tile to see the path to more assets. You can also delete the prefab buildings and replace with anything else from the prefab library! Want to add some vendors? Try dropping in a stall from the "market" collection.

- ADD BOATS: Drop in ships and boats from Forgotten Adventures or Tom Cartos to quickly populate your docks. If you use Token Magic FX module, you can add a drop shadow to those boats.

- OPTIMIZE: If you want to optimize your scene, try using the Tile Flattener feature of DF Architect module. This will turn all of the separate tiles into a single background tile! Best to use Chrome for this since it gives you the very efficient WEBP option. see my tutorial on DF Architect for more info.

Welcome. I'm Baileywiki, and thanks for trying out my maps for Foundry VTT. Some things you want to know:

UPDATE 10/22/20: Now using core Foundry lighting so Dancing Lights module is no longer needed.

 

These Maps Be Upgradable!

These maps are all free. But most of these maps also have (or will have) the ability to be upgraded and customized. Clear out a dilapidated mansion and then work to take it over as a base. Turn a wizard's room into a cleric's temple... or a druid's garden. Commandeer a sailing vessel and upgrade it over time.

I have a Patreon for fans who value this kind of extensibility of game play at https://www.patreon.com/baileywiki 

 

Modules in Use

The Baileywiki modules use a variety of 3rd party modules to make the technical magic possible. The current list of Required and Recommended modules can be found in this section of the Baileywiki Installation Guide & FAQ.

While only Token Attacher and Libwrapper are required, we highly recommend you use one of the suggested Module Loadouts to make the most of the technical features within the module.

 

About the Multiportal

The Multiportal is a special map that can be easily changed within Foundry. Just open up the Config for the map, find the main map image, and browse to the module directory > modules/baileywiki-maps/maps/multiportal/. Inside that directory are many different types of portals like Fire, Fey or Void. See below for the full list.

Portal Type Customization: just go into the module folder and find alternative types. 

Modules in Use: (optional)

  • Core Foundry Lights: for a pulsing effect. Turn on Night cycle to see it best.
  • Token Magic FX: The river and portal itself will shimmer with magic effect
  • FXMaster: Turn on Stars or Embers, and Fog, and set them to a similar color as your portal choice. It really sets the ambiance!
  • Wall Height: The towers at the bridge are only 20 feet high so flying players can see over them.

Available Upgrades: Patreons get access to the original Dungeondraft file that lets you manipulate this map as much as you like and create new portal types with one click!

The premium Foundry module also comes with a few more portal types in the pack.

Available portals (in this module):

  • Fire
  • Ice
  • Void
  • To save on module size, the rest are available for free at my Patreon page:
    • Acid
    • Earth
    • Fey/Forest
    • Rot
    • Shadow
    • Space
    • Water

Communicate with me anytime at my Discord or via Patreon.

cf.path: Baileywiki Nuts and Bolts#/CF_SEP/Quick Encounters#/CF_SEP/The Hideout

text.content:
Quick Encounter

The cult has been attempting human sacrifices to bargain with a demon lord. Up til now, they have been unsuccessful. Up til now, they have also only tried sacrificing adults. The party finds the third missing child bound in chains with the cult's leader (Night Hag) reading components and incantations to sacrifice them, the stakes are clear.

An optional feature of this encounter is Ritual Progress. Depending upon the desired difficulty of the encounter and percieved "threat level" of the party, the Hag can work towards the ritual using one of the following frameworks:

  1.  Easy. The hag knows that attempting to sacrifice the child now will not yield the desired result of summoning a demonic servant, they need more time. The Hag will not attempt to further the ritual.
  2. Medium. The hag knows that attempting to sacrifice the child now will not yield the desired result of summoning a demonic servant, they need more time. If the battle is going poorly (Hell Hound loses 1/2 HP or the Night Hag loses 1/4 HP), the hag will use a lair action on initiative count 20 to progress the ritual. After 3 of these lair actions, the child is sacrificed. Due to the hasty nature of the ritual, a demon is not summoned, but the Night Hag is restored to full health and recovers all expended spell uses.
  3. Hard. The hag knows that attempting to sacrifice the child now will not yield the desired result of summoning a demonic servant, they need more time. No matter, with these fools dead they can acquire a new sacrifice. The hag will use a lair action on initiative count 20 to progress the ritual. After 3 of these lair actions, the child is sacrificed. Consider reducing the "progress" of the ritual by 1 "stage" when the Hag recieves a critical hit or large amount of damage. Due to the hasty nature of the ritual, a demon is not summoned, but the Night Hag is restored to full health and recovers all expended spell uses.

The child can be rescued before the fight is over. They are clad in chains, but these can be removed. Possible solutions include: high DC strength check (DC 20), medium DC sleight of hand/lockpicking check (DC 15), a spell to destroy the chains, magical attacks (as if by a magical weapon etc.). If the child is freed, the hag must be within 5ft of them to continue progressing the ritual. If the hag fails to be within 5ft of the child for two lair actions in a row, the ritual is thwarted.

If Lady Cochraine has been recruited to aid in the fight, she will prioritize breaking the chains and freeing the child (recommend a flat DC 11 check for Lady Cochraine to break the chains).

  • 1@Compendium[dnd5e.monsters.xvh2UOKv1bh03Gih]{Night Hag} (1800XP each)
  • 1@Compendium[dnd5e.monsters.iSCL4Q82ivnYelzc]{Hell Hound} (700XP each)

text.content:
The main deck of the Ghost Galleon is ready for a free spooky encounter.  To explore the other 5 levels of ship and much more, download the Ghost Galleon PNGs from https://www.patreon.com/baileywiki 

UPDATE 10/22/20: Now using core Foundry lighting so Dancing Lights module is no longer needed.

 

Modules in Use

The Baileywiki modules use a variety of 3rd party modules to make the technical magic possible. The current list of Required and Recommended modules can be found in this section of the Baileywiki Installation Guide & FAQ.

While only Token Attacher and Libwrapper are required, we highly recommend you use one of the suggested Module Loadouts to make the most of the technical features within the module.

 

About the Ghost Galleon

This was once a mighty 6-level sailing vessel meant to serve as a battlemap and base of operations for your crew. But it's been taken over by... ghosts? Cursed pirates? Let your players clean it out, and then offer them the magically renovated Galleon as a mobile base for their next campaign arc. The normal Galleon is available for free in the module's compendium.

Alternative Layouts: This map is available initially as a "Multi-scene Map".  It is meant for parties to go through scene by scene. However, you can always use the scene artwork to recreate all of the levels in a single map, if that's your preference. Use a copy of the "Galleon Single Map" from the Compendium as an easy starting point. you'll just need to update all of your Multilevel Token hotspots to a unique map name.

Modules in Use: Multilevel Token hotspots are in place, including the Hold, the Decks and the ocean. Core Foundry Lighting for green torch fire. And FXMaster for creating eerie green fog and supernatural starlight.

Special Use of Multilevel Token: On the main deck are special MLT zones. Some on the Decks and a big zone in the water. You can place actors anywhere on this Main Deck screen, and they will "project" to the same spot from other screens. This way your players can see each other and enemies from anywhere on the ship (assuming line of sight). You should also be able to target these clones in combat (if you're using the Single Map version). It is important that you don't drop Actors directly in the "projected" hotspots. They won't project to other areas, and you may lose track of where you put them. Just drop them into the Main Deck screen or one of the rooms.

Special Use of Ambient Sounds: In each level of the Galleon you can hear sailing sounds whenever you select a token. These sounds become louder or more muffled as you exit/enter cabins or go further below deck. They are the loudest on the Main Deck outside.

 

Available Upgrades

The free version of the Ghost Galleon includes the main deck. Patreons get access to the other 4 levels of the ship!

 

Communicate with me anytime at my Discord or via Patreon.

text.content:
Quick Encounter

There is an eating area and small kitchen within the hideout. One cultist is preparing food, while a second is finishing a meal. Given their position within the hideout, these two are unlikely to be the first engaged and will easily hear commotion. They will run to their allies if they hear fighting, but may take longer to fully prepare themselves (lower initiative, recommended -5).

If they party assaults the bunk room first and are not too loud, they could sneak through the secret passageway to the kitchen to stealthily eliminate the cook and diner.

cf.path: Baileywiki Nuts and Bolts#/CF_SEP/Scene Notes#/CF_SEP/Landing Pages

text.content:
Baileywiki Landing Pages - Configuration Tool ReadMe

Congratulations on setting up a Landing Page for your Campaign! Whether you're setting up an atmospheric way for your players to prepare themselves for their untimely demise, or just want a scenic location for perusing your notes, you've come to the right place!

 

While you may choose to "set it and forget it" on your landing page(s), there's a lot of power in being able to quickly and easily update your page between sessions. Head out of the big city and into the wild open countryside? Plumbing the depths of a sunken temple? Party managed to sink the town into a hellscape? This guide helps you make thematic changes to your landing pages with just a few clicks of a button!


Note: The Configurable Landing Page controls require the Monk's Active Tile Triggers and Tagger modules to function. Glow effects and Weather effects require the Token Magic FX and FXMaster modules respectively.

 

Using the Configuration Tool I: What, and Where is it?

The Configuration tool is an un-obtrusive tile in the top-right corner of all of the Baileywiki "Configurable" Landing Pages. It's icon looks like a wrench and a gear. It is a Monk's Active Tile set to "on click" for only GM's that opens a menu for configuring your landing pages. You probably clicked on it to get here!

 

The Configuration Tool allows you to drastically alter your landing pages without the need for mass editing or changing Monk's Active Tile Trigger actions. You can also copy and paste the tile to use it on other scenes. 

 

Using the Configuration Tool II: The Main Menu

The Configuration Tool first opens to the "Main Menu" where you can select what to change about the current scene's themes. Click on a menu to alter those settings. Each menu has a button to return to the main menu if you want to change another setting.

 

There is also a button to open this ReadMe from the main menu.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Configuration Tool Menus: Entire Theme

The "Entire Theme" menu allows you to change all of the tiles and text colors, the sigil glow effect, and the scene weather to one of 6 custom presets that suit most backgrounds. Preset themes can also be applied to individual elements with their respective menus to mix and match presets and custom settings. The themes are:
Frost: A white and pale blue theme with misty fog.

Gothic: A red and yellow theme with moonlit clouds and flying bats.

Golden: A golden theme with twinkling lights.

Radiant: A white and ivory theme with clouds and white birds.

Natural: A green theme with forest fog and falling leaves

Eldritch: A purple and blue theme with swirling fog and bubbles

 

The Theme Selector also lists all of the tags that are affected by the Configuration tool.

 

 

 

 

 

Configuration Tool Menus: Sigil and Frame

The Sigil and Frame menu contains two submenus: image customization and color customization.

 

Changes within this menu and its submenus affect all tiles with the menu-frame tag. Note that image selection uses the "switch image" action, and so will not have any affect on tiles that do not have images assigned. On pre-built pages this is the medalian above the landing page menu and all of the "line work" around the page.

 

 

 

 

Sigil and Frame: Image Customization

The image customization submenu for Sigils and Frames allows you to cycle through the next and previous options in the Frame images. You can also switch to the color customization submenu for the Sigil and Frames.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Sigil and Frame: Color Customization

The color customization submenu allows you to set the color of the Sigil and Frames. You can select from one of the presets to only affect the Sigil and Frame colors, or you can choose a custom color with a color picker. You can also switch to the image customization submenu for the Sigil and Frames

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Configuration Tool Menus: Text

The Text configuration menu lets you set the color of the text on the page. You can choose from one of the six presets which will only change the text elements on the page, or you can select a custom color with a color picker.

 

Changes in this menu will affect all text with the menu-text tag and all tiles with the menu-tile tag. On pre-built pages, this is all of the text labels and the arrows next to the landing page menu tiems.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Configuration Tool Menus: Menu Spotlight

The Menu Spotlight configuration menu lets you set the color of the spotlight on the page. You can choose from one of the six presets which will only change the menu spotlight on the page, or you can select a custom color with a color picker.

 

Changes on this menu will affect all tiles with the menu-extra tag. On pre-built pages this is the tile around the landing page menu and sigil.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Configuration Tool Menus: Sigil Glow

The Sigil Glow menu lets you set the Token Magic FX glow on the menu sigil. You can choose from one of the six presets, or select two custom colors with a color picker.

 

Changes on this menu will affect all entities with the menu-sigil tag and requires Token Magic FX. On pre-built pages this is only the sigil medalion above the landing page menu.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Configuration Tool Menus: Weather and Atmosphere

The Weather and Atmosphere menu lets you set the FXMaster weather for the scene. You can choose from one of the six presets, or clear the weather if you prefer not to have it on.

 

This feature only affects the scene weather and requires FXMaster.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Further Use for the Configuration Tool

Because the Configuration Tool works off of tags, you don't need to change anything about its Monk's Active Tile Triggers setup. If you'd like to use the Configuration Tool on other scenes, simply copy and paste the tile to the appropriate scene and you're off!

Similarly, if you'd like to add more elements to a landing page and you want them to change with things like your frames and sigil, just add the tiles and tag them according to the menu that you think is best.

cf.path: Baileywiki Nuts and Bolts#/CF_SEP/Scene Notes#/CF_SEP/Docks

text.content:
Dunkirk Harbor is a large area of the docks between the Wharfmaster and the Market. It features a granary, a 3-story inn, and shops with apartments above them. There is also a large, popular tavern and inn featuring a fighting pit where long-traveled seamen like to blow off steam and earn some coin.

 

Vessels of all sizes use Dunkirk.

 

 

Modules in use:

- Token Attacher: useful for moving or replacing prefabs or rotating cargo cranes. The cranes are set to a high z value and as overhead tiles. This lets them swing over the cargo areas of most ships.

- Multilevel Token: used to teleport your players from the tavern "facade" to the detailed "fighting pit" tavern. Make sure you import that scene into your world, and that your multilevel token regions are named the same!

- Levels, Better Roofs and Wall Height for the upper floors of the buildings

 

Other suggestions:

- CUSTOMIZE: Rearrange the docks as you like using the tiles. Double-click any dock tile to see the path to more assets. You can also delete the prefab buildings and replace with anything else from the prefab library! Want to add some vendors? Try dropping in a stall from the "market" collection.

- ADD BOATS: Drop in ships and boats from Forgotten Adventures or Tom Cartos to quickly populate your docks. If you use Token Magic FX module, you can add a drop shadow to those boats.

- OPTIMIZE: If you want to optimize your scene, try using the Tile Flattener feature of DF Architect module. This will turn all of the separate tiles into a single background tile! Best to use Chrome for this since it gives you the very efficient WEBP option. see my tutorial on DF Architect for more info. When you're done customizing, you can also use the "Delete All Control Tokens" macro to unattach everything and delete control tokens. Be careful, you can't undo this!

cf.path: Baileywiki Nuts and Bolts#/CF_SEP/Module ReadMe's

text.content:
The Baileywiki module features special assets in the Actors Compendium which leverage the Token Attacher module. We refer to these collectively as "Prefabs" and you will see that terminology used throughout Baileywiki modules, documents, and videos.

While this free module has many of these special assets, there are hundreds only available in the Baileywiki Premium Maps and Baileywiki Towns modules which you can get on Patreon. https://www.patreon.com/baileywiki 

 

NOTE: Default DPI for Placeables

We attempt to use a standardized DPI of 150 the module artwork. This means that if you are using your tile browser to drop in tiles and artwork, you will need to set the "Asset Grid Size" to 150 for the tiles to match your grid (the grid size of your scene does not matter thanks to how Foundry handles tiles). If you leave it at the default of 100, the images may appear larger than intended, conversely, if you use a larger Asset Grid Size of 300, the images will appear smaller.

NOTE: Modules in Use

  • Wall Height: Establishes height for walls so players can see over them. Good for tactical battles and for multilevel prefabs and maps
  • Better Roofs: Automatically hides roofs in all building prefabs
  • Levels: Creates the ability to build maps in 3 dimensions, requiresWall Height and Better Roofs.
  • Token Attacher Module: (required): This module allows any elements to be attached to tokens and then dropped direclty into a map. Those elements are stored with the Actor/Token if the data is linked.

There are additional modules used within the maps and prefabs, but the above four are integral to making the modular pieces of this module work.

 

Manipulating and Deleting Prefabs

Prefabs are controlled via "control tokens," these are usually small white "dots" or "houses" near the structures they are connected to. You can move, rotate, and delete entire prefab structures by moving, rotating, or deleting their control tokens.

Control tokens also control the size of prefabs. If you would like to make a prefab larger or smaller, open the token menu of the control token (double right-click) and adjust the height and width in the "Image" tab. This is particularly useful when working with natural elements such as trees, bushes, and terrain.

text.content:
The docks thin out as one gets further from the main market center. Along the coast, a few docks are maintained. More often used by smugglers trying to avoid the more popular commercial lanes, the Coastal Docks can accommodate smaller vessels or ferrying with barges and smaller craft. 

 

 

Modules in use:

- Token Attacher: If you drag ship prefabs like the Galleon, Frigate or Triremes. The docks is plenty long to accommodate a couple of large ships.

- Levels, Better Roofs and Wall Height for the lighthouse.

 

Other suggestions:

- CUSTOMIZE: Rearrange the docks as you like using the tiles. Double-click any dock tile to see the path to more assets. You can also delete the prefab buildings and replace with anything else from the prefab library! Want to add some vendors? Try dropping in a stall from the "market" collection.

- ADD BOATS: Drop in ships and boats from Forgotten Adventures or Tom Cartos to quickly populate your docks. If you use Token Magic FX module, you can add a drop shadow to those boats.

- OPTIMIZE: If you want to optimize your scene, try using the Tile Flattener feature of DF Architect module. This will turn all of the separate tiles into a single background tile! Best to use Chrome for this since it gives you the very efficient WEBP option. see my tutorial on DF Architect for more info.

cf.path: Baileywiki Nuts and Bolts#/CF_SEP/Scene Notes#/CF_SEP/Ships

text.content:
Welcome. I'm Baileywiki, and thanks for trying out my maps for Foundry VTT. Some things you want to know:

UPDATE 10/22/20: Now using core Foundry lighting so Dancing Lights module is no longer needed.

For a complete walkthrough of the Trireme, go here and jump to the Trireme timestamp.

These Maps Be Upgradable!

These maps are all free. But most of these maps also have (or will have) the ability to be upgraded and customized. Clear out a dilapidated mansion and then work to take it over as a base. Turn a wizard's room into a cleric's temple... or a druid's garden. Commandeer a sailing vessel and upgrade it over time.

I have a Patreon for fans who value this kind of extensibility of game play at https://www.patreon.com/baileywiki 

 

Quick Tips

  1. The Multi-Level Token zones are controlled via map notes. Make sure that both you and your players have Map Notes Display set to True.
  2. If you would like to control whether players can use a specific zone, you can change the permissions of the given map note by changing between the @Compendium[baileywiki-nuts-and-bolts.journals.Ii2M77LabDmpHbGt]{stair} and @Compendium[baileywiki-nuts-and-bolts.journals.Ic3LUzSx7smMJBoB]{gm-only} journal entries. If you are using Scene Packer, then these entries will be imported and linked automatically.
  3. Many of the tiles, lights, drawings and sounds are locked in place by Token Attacher module. Use Token Attacher's Quick Edit mode to move most things around.

 

Modules in Use

The Baileywiki modules use a variety of 3rd party modules to make the technical magic possible. The current list of Required and Recommended modules can be found in this section of the Baileywiki Installation Guide & FAQ.

While only Token Attacher and Libwrapper are required, we highly recommend you use one of the suggested Module Loadouts to make the most of the technical features within the module.

 

About the Trireme

A trireme is a tactical military vessel meant to transport troops, and attacks with its ram or by boarding vessels. This map is available initially as a "Single Map". While I can deploy it as a multi-scene map, a Single Map might be better for combat and to cut down on load times for your players. Plus it lets you control weather and lighting from one map instead of 6 of them. 

Modules in Use: Multilevel Token hotspots are in place, including the Hold, the Decks and the ocean. And FXMaster for creating lovely clouds rolling by.

Special Use of Multilevel Token: On the main deck are special MLT zones. Some on the Decks and a big zone in the water. You can place actors anywhere on this Main Deck screen, and they will "project" to the same spot from other screens. This way your players can see each other and enemies from anywhere on the ship (assuming line of sight). You should also be able to target these clones in combat (if you're using the Single Map version). It is important that you don't drop Actors directly in the "projected" hotspots. They won't project to other areas, and you may lose track of where you put them. Just drop them into the Main Deck screen or one of the rooms.

Special Use of Ambient Sounds: In each level of the Galleon you can hear sailing sounds whenever you select a token. These sounds become louder or more muffled as you exit/enter cabins or go further below deck. They are the loudest on the Main Deck outside.

Available Upgrades: For Patreons, your party can upgrade their Trireme in lots of ways. Change out the Ram with one of 6 variants for more Attack Power, change the Hull for a larger battle space and Armor Class, add an entirely new level of Rowers and new rooms for extra SPEED, or change up your Sails to another color for a different motif. There's also a "night time" version of the upgraded deck with tents and lighting.

Finally, the Trireme is available as a placeable asset (using the Token Attacher module) so you can drop it into any map.

Communicate with me anytime at my Discord or via Patreon. 

 

About the Main Deck Outside

The Main Deck Outside features:

  1. Staircases to various tiers
  2. Teleport hotspots to travel to other rooms. You must be standing in a teleport zone, and then click the Anchor icon to actually teleport.
  3. Projection regions on each deck and in the water to project Actor tokens to all other levels

Try changing the weather and night/day modes to mix things up!

 

About the Lower Deck Rooms and Captains Quarters

The Lower Deck includes a Storage Room on the left-hand side, and the Captain's Quarters  on the right-hand-side.

The Captains Quarters can be reached from the Main Deck Outside. Look for the subtle mounted torch that marks the doorway.

 

About the Bilge

The bilge of a trireme is used for storage of the oars and other provisions. You can decorate this how you like or just smuggle that small village to safety.

Quick Encounter

It's almost striking to see some of these rooms in the lower levels filled with such recent activity. The recent use of the kitchens is certainly less striking than the cook though: a Green Hag accompanied by  a small brood of Cockatrices. The Hag does not take kindly to interruptions and immediately sics her Cockatrices on the party.

 

The Hag is caught unawares if the party enters the kitchens without having disturbed the "feast" in the adjoining hall. Should the feast be disrupted, the Hag and Cockatrices are poised and ready at the door to attack the party, but do not join the fray until the party opens the door.

 

  • 3@Compendium[dnd5e.monsters.EpYl7qifM5pq6W6B]{Cockatrice} (100XP each)
  • 1@Compendium[dnd5e.monsters.saq6WM959pKHuaqP]{Green Hag} (700XP each)

cf.path: Baileywiki Nuts and Bolts#/CF_SEP/Scene Notes#/CF_SEP/Castles

text.content:
In the Elevator After the trap has sprung:

The elevator doors are locked shut by some mechanism. It would be very difficult to pry them open, however, careful inspection in the ceiling of the elevator car revelas that there is a trap door for service access. If the players discover this, they can push the trapdoor out of the way and ascend to the painting area on @Compendium[baileywiki-maps-premium-towns.maps.DAbGTRZcFz4V7lVb]{Castle Gothic Level 04}.

 

If they discover this, move the "climb up" map note onto the elevator car on @Compendium[baileywiki-maps-premium-towns.maps.IIog9zIN76LS1pRg]{Castle Gothic Level 03}. On all other levels, there is too much distance between the car's resting place and the top of the car for climbing up to be of much help.

 

Near the Painting in the Towers:

Virtually impossible to detect is a certain looseness in the cracked stones in front of the painting. If the party detects this and begins to move the stone tiles, they realize that a large section is actually a single piece and the roof to a trap door.

If the elevator trap on @Compendium[baileywiki-maps-premium-towns.maps.ygiA0M16oVih5DoQ]{Castle Gothic Level B1} has not yet sprung, then they can peer down the shaft to the bottom, some 200 feet below.

 

If the elevator trap has sprung, then they can use the trap door and the access hatch in the roof of the elevator car to pass between the towers and @Compendium[baileywiki-maps-premium-towns.maps.IIog9zIN76LS1pRg]{Castle Gothic Level 03}. This is not very helpful unless they have also opened the doors to the elevator car. Move the "trapdoor down" map note to in front of the painting, within the drawing.

text.content:
Your tokens (and/or tiles) and their positions have been saved in this Journal Entry and replaced with a single Quick Encounter Note. To run the Quick Encounter, double-click the Map Note icon and then click the Run Quick Encounter button.

Quick Encounter

This large hall is filled with an eerie fog. Small ruts and stains on the floor indicate where there were once banquet halls. As the mist swirls, the party gets glimpses of the spirits of the servants whose last meal was cut short in these halls. Seated around long-gone tables and benches is an array of Ghosts and Specters going through the motions of a dinner. If the party disrupts that dinner, they are not likely to be welcome guests for much longer. Playing along and avoiding walking where there are tables though may keep the spirits in their merry-making state.

 

  • 5@Compendium[dnd5e.monsters.PuPo4H4Dcxigf0fY]{Specter} (200XP each)
  • 3@Compendium[dnd5e.monsters.qoFEjfrANBdrCP6m]{Ghost} (1100XP each)

Quick Encounter

The Castle Steward (Knight) is seated at his desk when the party bursts in, a dragon statue looming above the door. While the party can attempt to reason with the Steward, he is loyal to the Lord of the Castle to a fault, and will attempt to persuade the party to either surrender, or leave. Failing that, the Steward snaps his fingers, the sign for the Red Dragon Wyrmling (marked hidden when this quick encounter is activated) to drop the statue act and bathe the party in fire before joining the Steward in the fight.

 

  • 1@Compendium[dnd5e.monsters.zgWkII3VoE4AHCND]{Red Dragon Wyrmling} (1100XP each)
  • 1@Compendium[dnd5e.monsters.D5UqYD1EnTrJaMTO]{Knight} (700XP each)

cf.path: Baileywiki Nuts and Bolts#/CF_SEP/Scene Notes

text.content:
Leighfair Crossing features an established stronghold built for defending one of the few safe areas to cross the Sulifin River. The captain of the Stronghold operates like a local magistrate, collecting taxes and providing protection and legal oversight for the surrounding villages. 

The Stronghold itself features 10 to 20 foot stone walls, 9 towers (many equipped with balconies and arrow slits), and a large drawbridge and gate with murder holes and a portcullis.

On the other side of the river stands a guard tower with arrow slits at the top.

Some trees can be found around the Stronghold to provide shade for travelers, or cover.

 

 

Modules in use:

- Ambient Doors: Provides a satisfying close/open sound to the portcullis.

- Token Attacher: useful for moving or replacing prefabs.

- Levels, Better Roofs and Wall Height for the upper floors of the buildings

- Try hiding the drawbridge tile to pull it up!

 

Other suggestions:

- CUSTOMIZE: Rearrange the map as you like using the tiles. Double-click any tile to see the path to more assets. You can also delete the prefab buildings and replace with anything else from the prefab library! Try adding some tactical elements or even a basement or dungeon in the scene or in the scene margins (using Active Tiles or Multilevel token to teleport players)

- OPTIMIZE: If you want to optimize your scene, try using the Tile Flattener feature of DF Architect module. This will turn all of the separate tiles into a single background tile! Best to use Chrome for this since it gives you the very efficient WEBP option. see my tutorial on DF Architect for more info. When you're done customizing, you can also use the "Delete All Control Tokens" macro to unattach everything and delete control tokens. Be careful, you can't undo this!

text.content:
Welcome. I'm Baileywiki, and thanks for trying out my maps for Foundry VTT. Some things you want to know:

UPDATE 10/22/20: Now using core Foundry lighting so Dancing Lights module is no longer needed.

These Maps Be Upgradable!

These maps are all free. But most of these maps also have (or will have) the ability to be upgraded and customized. Clear out a dilapidated mansion and then work to take it over as a base. Turn a wizard's room into a cleric's temple... or a druid's garden. Commandeer a sailing vessel and upgrade it over time.

I have a Patreon for fans who value this kind of extensibility of game play at https://www.patreon.com/baileywiki 

 

GM Walkthrough Video

For a complete walkthrough of the Docks, watch the YouTube Video. (Spoilers ahead!)

Quick Tips

  1. The Multi-Level Token zones are controlled via map notes. Make sure that both you and your players have Map Notes Display set to True.
  2. If you would like to control whether players can use a specific zone, you can change the permissions of the given map note by changing between the @Compendium[baileywiki-maps-premium.journals.Jy46aEPppzhz5Rqn]{stair} and @JournalEntry[JL767aPVxqeZatHy]{gm-only} journal entries. If you are using Scene Packer, then these entries will be imported and linked automatically.
  3. Some of the tiles, lights, drawings and sounds are locked in place by Token Attacher module. Use Token Attacher's Quick Edit mode to move most things around.
  4. Make sure that you have all of the connected maps that you want to use (ie: @Compendium[baileywiki-maps-premium.maps.Vo82QxlfeeFY9242]{Docks} and @Scene[fkY31HQ31fZRVtnj]{Docks Sewer}) imported, otherwise teleports between the two maps will not work.

 

Modules in Use

The Baileywiki modules use a variety of 3rd party modules to make the technical magic possible. The current list of Required and Recommended modules can be found in this section of the Baileywiki Installation Guide & FAQ.

While only Token Attacher and Libwrapper are required, we highly recommend you use one of the suggested Module Loadouts to make the most of the technical features within the module.

 

About the Docks

For a complete walkthrough of the Docks, watch the YouTube Video. (Spoilers ahead!)

This is a large 50x50 map of docks that you would find at a harbor town or city. There are multiple areas to set skirmishes, meet NPCs. See below for a complete run-through of the areas of interest.

Modules in Use: Multilevel Token hotspots are in place to teleport your players around and to project them from level to another. And FXMaster for creating clouds, weather, bats and general ambieance.  Roofs & Overhead Tiles module will let you dynamically remove roofs as you explore the dock. And Token Attacher is useful if you want to drop the Galleon or Trireme boats into one of the ample docks, or if you want to deploy the Dock Crane arm, which can be rotated around.

Special Use of Ambient Sounds: In each level of the Dock you can hear ambient dock noises, crackling fires, dripping water and friendly music coming from the DockTavern.

 

Available Upgrades: The Docks have some significant upgrades, both available on Patreon. https://www.patreon.com/baileywiki 

 

First, the main dock area and the 1st level of the tavern ares free to everyone. But the Sewers under the docks, and the Basement and upper levels of the Tavern are for Patreons.

Just subscribe to Tier 2 or higher of my Patreon, and you'll get an entire Premium Module with one-click access to all the upgrades and maps.

Communicate with me anytime at my Discord or via Patreon. 

 

List of Rooms/Features

LVL0 Sewers: 5 entry points from the ground level, including 3 manholes and 2 pipes from the canal. The North Sewer features a secret door into a hidden room under the Tavern. The room has another secret door to the pantry of the Tavern. The South Sewer has a hidden room under the Dock Office, where likely an underground crime syndicate is operating. There is a ladder up to a secret entrance to the locked treasury, adjacent to the Dock Office.

LVL1 Docks: Multiple open docks to park sailing vessels like the droppable Galleon or Trireme (in your Actors compendium). Wharfmaster office. Tarriff and Treasury office. Dock Tavern. Multiple tents and merchant stalls. 5 Access points to the Sewers.

Dock Tavern: 

LVL1: Main dining area featuring Foundry 7.5 lighting and kitchen with basement access

LVL2: Guest rooms and balcony looking over the lower level. A meeting room.

LVL3: Attic and Tavernkeeper's abode. There is a secret room (no marked door) that you can use for whatever, and access to the balcony.

LVL4: Roof. No built-in way of getting there, but the GM can plop down an enterprising player who might want to sneak in or out of the Tavern via the roof.

 

Have a Problem or Questions? 

Communicate with me anytime at my Discord (best) or via Patreon.

cf.path: Baileywiki Nuts and Bolts

text.content:
About Nuts and Bolts

Overveiw

Welcome. We're Baileywiki and Zephyr, and thanks for trying out our modules for Foundry VTT. To keep up with our latest content, including Premium Foundry VTT modules and Dungeondraft files, become a patron.

The Baileywiki Nuts and Bolts module is just that: the nuts and bolts that hold our modules together. There are macros, journals, items, and assets that are used across our suite of Foundry modules. This keeps things unified and updated as much as possible. Whether you're accessing our content via module installation, or via Moulinette importing, having Nuts and Bolts installed in your world will keep everything running smoothly.

Within this journal entry specifically, you'll find information on our other modules and some of the resources available to you for troubleshooting and making the most out of the Baileywiki modules.  For the most up to date information  and guides, always check the Baileywiki Installation Guide & FAQ and the Baileywiki Modular System Guide for the change logs.

 

Included Assets

Nuts and Bolts includes the following compendiums:

  • Journal Entries - Journals used by, and with information about, the Baileywiki Family of Modules
  • Macros - Macros used by the Baileywiki Family of Modules and a collection of incredibly useful utility macros
  • Items - Items referenced by some of the interactive elements within the Baileywiki Family of Modules

Nuts and Bolts also includes core icons, sounds, and artwork that can be found within the respective module subfolders.

 

About the Baileywiki Family of Modules

The Baileywiki Family of Modules are made with a simple philosophy in mind: help everyday GM's to create truly amazing experiences for their players by combining art and technology. Using phenomenal art assets and Dungeondraft, we create scenes and tiles that can be used for a variety of campaigns and settings. We then leverage that art with the wealth of technical Foundry modules to create truly special features and interactions for GM's and players. Here's a little bit about our current library of modules:

  • Baileywiki Maps Pack (Free Module) - The Baileywiki Maps Pack is available for free to all Foundry VTT users through the Foundry VTT module browser. This is a sampling of all of our premium modules to give you a better idea of what we're all about. While it is a sampling it is by no means incomplete. There are whole maps and deployable buildings that are perfect for your next game.
  • Baileywiki Premium Maps - Premium Maps focuses on complete scenes and is a more "traditional" content module. These are keystone destinations like multi-story taverns, keeps, and magnificent mansions. Technology and modularityabound here: massive, deployable sailing ships; manors that can change their rooms and walls with the click of a button; versatile themes; and more. 
  • Baileywiki Modular Town - The Modular Town is a whole system for easily crating  town and city-based maps for either roleplay or battlemaps, complete with tactical elements, many different store and builing types, and even alternative terrains, weather and ambient loops. This is the ultimate set of building blocks for creating your own world and with over 100 example scenes, it comes with plenty of inspiration.
  • Baileywiki Cabal Dungeon - The Cabal Dungeon began as a community project to create truly modular dungeons for Foundry. There are deployable hall sections, rooms, set pieces, traps, and puzzles from Baileywiki, Zephyr, and community contribitors: Rathji and Ako22.
  • Baileywiki Modular City - The Modular City is a continuation of the concepts in the Modular Town: deployable buildings and systems for creating a truly urban environment for your games. There are a variety of themes and motifs to choose from with a litany of backgrounds, deployable assets, and example scenes. The Modular City is our current focus and is our largest project yet, spanning multiple modules with different themes. The current Modular City module are:
    • District 01 - Disctrict 01 is the "base" of the modular city project and includes neighborhoods, facades, and a massive manor-inn that can be customized and configured directly in-scene using Monk's Active Tile Triggers.
    • Disctrict 02: Docks - The City Docks focuses on Docks, the Sewers that run beneath them, and the ships that sail to them. Piers, boardwalks, and more.
    • Disctrict 03: Temples - The City Temples feature massive and complex temple towers that span up to 9 explorable stories to awe players.
    • Disctrict 04: Ruins and Slums - The City Ruins and Slums are all about the underbelly of the city. The neighborhoods that are forced to live in squalor, and the crumbling stones of abandoned districts.

All of our premium modules are available exclusively to our incredible Patrons. If you would like to support us and check out these modules, join us on Patreon.

 

Useful Resources

Video Guides

You can view release videos, system guides, and advanced tutorials on the Baileywiki YouTube Channel. Below are some helpful videos and playlists to have handy when getting started.

  • Installation and Getting Started Guide
  • Playlist of Release Videos: Modular System Releases
  • Playlist of guides to using the Modular system: Building with the Modular System
  • Playslist of Modular Map Walkthroughs: Baileywiki Map Walkthroughs
    • note: The release videos and walkthroughs cover content from all of our modules. If you can't find a scene or other asset referenced in one of the videos, check your active modules.

 

Quick Tips

  1. IMPORT MACROS: Import all of the macros from the Nuts and Bolts module. While Scene Packer will handle automatically importing and linking many macros, it is still important to have access to key macros like Token Attacher's "Quick Edit Mode" and other utility pieces. You only need to do this the first time that you install Nuts and Bolts and if there are any specific macros that have been updated (check the change notes).
  2. AGREE TO THE PROMPT: The Baileywiki modules are built in 5e and use a special Token Attacher script to import actors for other systems. The modules may prompt you to "Import a special compendium" when you first activate them, say "yes" to the prompt to import this data into your Compendium tab. This is a special "system agnostic" Actor compendium that will be refreshed every time there is a new release.
  3. DELETE UNNEEDED ACTORS AND SCENES: Importing a large amount of scenes and actors can cause high load times and server instability. Only import scenes and prefabs that you are actively using. Once you have finished using prefabs to build a scene, delete the actors from your actor directory.

 

Modules in Use

The Baileywiki modules use a variety of 3rd party modules to make the technical magic possible. The current list of Required and Recommended modules can be found in this section of the Baileywiki Installation Guide & FAQ.

While only Nuts and Bolts, Token Attacher, and Libwrapper are required, we highly recommend you use one of the suggested Module Loadouts to make the most of the technical features within the module.

Changelogs

The Changelogs for our modules are available in these documents:

  • Baileywiki Free Module Change Log
  • Baileywiki Nuts and Bolts Change Log
  • Baileywiki Premium Modules Change Log

 

Additional Tips

  1. Don't delete multiple control tokens at once. Do it one at a time or you'll get artifacts. 
  2. Hold CTRL when rotating assets or use the arrow keys to quickly rotate them 
  3. If after placing an asset the image is laying on top of another image, use the Tile tool to move it to the back. it won't hurt anything
  4. There are many ambient sounds and some loops included in the module files. Check em out.
  5. Instead of using the Actor assets, you can deploy images directly from the module files
  6. When you are done setting up your scene, "select all" actors and then right click one of them to make all of the control tokens invisible to your players
  7. Use walls to close off parts of the map to your players

 

Getting Support

If you're ever having trouble with one of the Baileywiki modules, you can consult the Baileywiki Installation Guide & FAQ for helpful guides, tips, and information on a variety of topics and features.

If you're still stuck, communicate with us anytime on the Baileywiki Discord Server(best) or via Patreon.

cf.path: Baileywiki Nuts and Bolts#/CF_SEP/Scene Notes#/CF_SEP/City

text.content:
The Manor is fashioned loosely after Trollskull Manor, and it can be used as an upgradeable base for your players. The Manor comes in four "base" versions, and most of the rooms can be dynamically swapped for other versions:

 

Base Versions

  • Empty. Decorate it yourself with Moulinette and Forgotten Adventures or Tom Cartos assets!
  • Ruined. The tavern was abandoned years ago, leaving cobwebs and detrius for your party.
  • Tavern. The tavern restored! Make some coin and upgrade it bit by bit, or all at once. Get the original Dungeondraft files to fully customize each room for your players!
  • Stronghold. Make the tavern your base! Complete with a magic laboratory, a cleric's sanctuary, a war room, sparring training room, and an armory. 

 

Walkthrough

A walkthrough of this content and its features is available on YouTube. Check out the full video here.

 

Key Features

  • 5 stories, including the cellar
  • Dynamic cellar door. Any player can click it to open it and activate the staircase.
  • Swappable rooms on every level including a stage or table in the tavern.
  • Controls in the scene margin to change the base layout, make a snowy environment, and more.
  • Dynamic lighting that also changes when the motif changes
  • Facade buildings surrounding the Manor, each of which can be swapped out for a real building
  • The chimneys feature animated or still versions of the smoke, using the control panel
  • Prefab ready! Put the Manor on any map since it's saved as a prefab actor

 

Modules in Use

  • Multiface Tiles. Right-click a room to see if you can change it out (GM  only)
  • Levels / Better Roofs / Wall Height: The triumverate of modules for 3-dimensional mapping
  • FXMaster: Clouds rolling by, except for over the Manor.
  • Monk's Active Tile Triggers with Tagger. Powers the controls in the margin of the scene.
  • Token Magic FX. Creates a satisfying drop shadow on roofs.
  • Token Attacher. For prefabs.

 

For support, find me on Discord.

text.content:
The brazier in the center of the room can be fed different substances to allow the party to teleport to other areas of the world.

 

To update the brazier room teleport, run the @Compendium[baileywiki-maps-premium-towns.macros.zrHfEhFEV2cV2i5a]{gothic-brazier-teleport-config} macro and select your desired destination. The MLT area is set to activate via map note and you can set the teleportation to nowhere ("Deactivate").

 

When the brazier room's teleportation is first made available to the players, you will need to drag the "teleport" map note into the room where the players can click on it. When teleporting is disabled, move the map note or change it to a gm-only journal entry.

 

There are 3 locations already placed in the gothic castle scenes, but more can be added. The 3 preset locations are:

 

  • gothic-braziertp-1: @Compendium[baileywiki-maps-premium-towns.maps.AF3z2j7rlAaWmnWh]{Castle Gothic Level B2} the Lord of the Castle's crypt, at the base of the stairs.
  • gothic-braziertp-2: @Compendium[baileywiki-maps-premium-towns.maps.IIog9zIN76LS1pRg]{Castle Gothic Level 03} the lounge, opposite the fireplace, near the doors to the Lord's chambers.
  • gothic-braziertp-3: @Compendium[baileywiki-maps-premium-towns.maps.DAbGTRZcFz4V7lVb]{Castle Gothic Level 04} the uppermost room of the main (heart) tower.

 

Do not change the text label of the drawing or you will break the macro. Open the macro for instructions on adding custom teleport codes and destinations.

name: The Town 05 Town Exit and Privisions
